original_title: Sri Lanka, India in talks on using Indian rupees to settle transactions: foreign minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is in talks with India on using the Indian rupee in settling cross-boarder transactions, Sri Lanka Foreign Minister Ali Sabry said thanking the regional superpower for providing its crisis-hit neighbour a lifeline.

“We are in discussion with India to accept the Indian currency as a common legal currency to work with. We hope that that will strengthen and integrate both economies and allow people-to-people contact and more movement,” Sabry said speaking to Indian reporters in New Delhi on Tuesday March 07.
“We’re grateful for what India has done; and we see India rising and we want to rise together,” he added.

The Indian High Commission in Colombo said on Monday that using Indian rupees for cross border transactions with Sri Lanka is being taken forward after banks started accounts enabling the process for tourism, and the possibility of expanding to settling trade and capital transactions.

Sabry said in his comments to the media in New Delhi that India has been the “greatest partner” in Sri Lanka’s recovery and stabilisation.

“I think all the other countries put together have not done what India has done for us. Its 3.9 billion US dollars credit line has given us a lifeline to fight another day, and we have fought together. So we’re very very grateful for India,” he said. (Colombo/Mar08/2023)
